oqJG-g_i8nU.title: The FPL Draft App That Changes Everything
oqJG-g_i8nU.transcript: This is the FPL Draft Zone, your fantasy [music] team's best signing of the season. Hello and welcome to the FPL Draft Zone, a podcast all about draft FPL. I'm Dom Crofts. I hope you are well and today we have a very special episode for you because I am joined by David Gurgis who has created an app specifically for us FPL draft managers. It's called Fantasy Footy. It's available online at fantasyfooty.xyz. It's available on the app store if you are an Apple user and it's coming to Android very soon indeed. David, thanks so much for joining us. >> No, no, thank you for having me. We're going to get right into your app very shortly and show off all its amazing features. But before we do that, you are out in Canada. There is loads of fantasy sport for Canadians out there. Loads and loads of options and yet you have chosen to set up a fantasy draft app for FPL. How did your obsession with FPL draft come about? >> Yeah. No, so I've always been in uh involved in soccer uh or football as you guys call it there. Um, so I've been playing it, been watching it as a kid. I used to go to school, come back, have to put in a VHS tape, uh, to record the games that was whatever was playing for my dad. Uh, and used to watch them again after work. Um, so was always involved. Played soccer growing up as a kid. Played today. Um, and then just started playing fantasy sports or fantasy soccer specifically um, not too long ago, couple years ago. Started with the World Cup actually the previous one. Um, was killing it, doing amazing. Then I actually went to the World Cup, didn't do I forgot about the fantasy app and then came back and then just started with fantasy uh in the Premier League in the FPL and then started playing the uh fantasy draft a lot more and just got really into it. >> Got into it so much that you've decided to create an app for draft managers. How do you even go about doing something like that? >> Yeah. Yeah. No, so I'm a software developer uh in essence and so I was just looking at stats and trying to understand um more data from the league and our our like our league with my group of friends that we were playing with and just wanted to know who was unlucky, who was lucky, what if this would have happened if I had this trade, would I have won? Would I have would that have changed any outcome? And just started pulling data, writing scripts and going from there. Fantastic. Well, let's get into the app then. First of all, we're going to take you through some of the features. So, the appeal of this app for me is that it's got loads of little nuggets that you cannot get anywhere else. It has got your live head-to-head tracking, so you can follow your matches every game week live. Gives you full point breakdowns, projected points, automatic subs, indicators for players on track for bonus points, defensive contributions as well. It also does transfer activity insight, so you can track how active each manager has been in the transfer market, which players have moved around the most between teams. What I love, one of the features I really love is the manager performance stats. So, obviously you have the league table in FPL Draft, but you can create in your app league tables based on loads of other metrics. whose team has scored the most goals, who's got the most assists, bonus points, how that impacts the way the league table would look if that was the chief metric. And then you've got unlucky stats. Tell us what unlucky stats are. >> Yeah. So, that was one of the reasons why I made the app in the start was I wanted to calculate was I just unlucky in my I guess in my matchups. Did someone else have easier matchups? Were they always versing someone that was scoring less? Um, so basically the unlucky stats uh takes everyone's scores every week, calculates the median and sees if you scored above it or below it. And if you scored below the median and you uh or if you scored above the median and lost, then you're considered unlucky. And we do that every week to week. Um, and we keep track of it. And then we create a table where you can calculate who is the most lucky and unlucky person. Um, and you can see everyone's stats there. Um, so we have a a metric to measure how unlucky you were instead of someone just claiming to be the unluckiest. >> Absolutely brilliant. It's also got bench points lost which tracks how many points each manager has lost to the bench across the season. And another one that I absolutely love is the whatif tool. So tell us what the whatif tool is. >> Yeah, so that's another one of uh the popular features I think people love using. Um, basically it calculates what if I was to swap with someone else's schedule. Um, would I have would I have ranked or would I be in a different position? So, if I had someone else's schedule, would I be first, would I be second? And it does that with everyone and calculates your best swap. So, if who would I have swapped or who should I have swapped with and been highest ranking in my league right now? >> Brilliant stuff. Well, what we've done is we have taken all the data from your app and we've plugged it into one of our leagues, which is the FPL Draft Zone Championship. There are three leagues at the FPL Draft Zone and the Championship is the Middle League. It's got 10 managers in. It is a head-to-head format. So, let's first of all take a look at the league analytics page that pops up on the app when you load it up. The league analytics on the lefth hand side, if you're watching us on YouTube, has quick stats. So, it has the most FPL points in that league. So, the team top of the league, well, not necessarily top of the league, I suppose, but the team who's accured the most points, which in this case after 24 gameweeks is 1,152. It has the fewest FPL points. It has the total matches played and the point spread. And it also has little individual stats that give you bragging rights over your mate. So, the top gameweek score of the season so far, 75 points, which I'm proud to say was my team. Uh and the best win streak in the league, six wins on the spin and that goes to Liam Smith whose side is draft excluded and who are top of the table as you can see in the middle column. Current win streaks are also ranked. So I have a twoame win streak right now and that puts me top. And then on the right hand side is a little line graph which you can plot every single team into and that tells you week by week where you were in the league at any given week and plots out your entire season. So that is that's the the sort of the league analytics tool. This is something I absolutely love which is all leagues combined. Tell us what this is. >> Yeah, so this is on the website actually. So, this allows you if you're in multiple leagues, you can just input both all your leagues into your account and then you can combine them to see how you rank um throughout all your leagues and how everyone ranks in that sense. And it has the league name in them. And that's why you can see that there's different league names for everyone. >> Yeah. So, this is four different leagues. We've got the three FPL draft zone leagues and also one of my local leagues. And these are the top 10 total scores across those leagues. So shout outs to Tyler Keller, Liam Smith, and Tom Waldy who make up the top four. Dan Walker just missing out on the top four. He's in fifth. And George Stthopoulos is down in 10th. But very competitive when you look at that. That is like almost like the ultimate draft league, isn't it? It's fantastic idea. We've also got the best manager tool, which is another really interesting one. Obviously, you've got the league table, which is what it's all about, but this is how other metrics measure your teams. So, a reminder that in this league, Liam Smith is top, Mike Whitefield is second, and I am third. So, the total points are on the left hand column of the screen if you're watching this on YouTube. Liam's got 49 points, Mike's got 45, and I've got 42. But if you look at the goals on the right hand side of this screen in the third column, that tells you an awful lot about why Liam is top of the league because he's side has scored 223 goals. And that is miles clear of anyone else in this league. I'm down in sixth with 164 and Mike who's third has got 171. So, this is the sort of thing, David, where you sort of look at these stats almost through a different lens because you're looking at them and you're going, actually, that's where I'm failing. That's where I'm succeeding. And I think we've got more of that on the next page because in the assist ranking, if you look on the left hand side of this column, Mike, who's second in the league, is ninth for assists. And Liam, who's top, is down in sixth. Pretty crazy. The same could be said about clean sheets. Mike's got a pretty good defensive record. His title challenge is built on defense from the looks of it. And I'm down in ninth with just 101 clean sheets. And then saves. I'm up in second with 25. And Mike is down in 12th. And Liam is eighth. Bonus points. Liam is well clear and I am in third. And Mike Whitefield second in the league down in 64. So, what would you say when you're looking at these sort of metrics and you're looking at the differences? Do you as a manager, as a draft manager, look at these and go, "Okay, I need to get players in who are scoring more goals. I need to get players in who are scoring more bonus points." Do you look at them and do you use them for your own draft team and try and work out where it is you're going wrong? >> Yeah. No, that's exactly where I do use them actually. I look at them, you see a breakdown of where you're lacking, where you're not lacking, and I try to adjust it. So, if I'm if I'm really low in I guess um like like goals, then maybe I'm going to need to try to fix up my forwards, my mids, see maybe get more attacking mids um and and just try to fix that up because you can generally see a th a trend when you look at players that are top in the league and then when you're looking at yourself and try to improve your squad as much as you can. Um and the website has even more of a breakdown where you can see uh by position uh by by players and so on. Um, so I can look at my my defense and see how I rank defensively in my league versus maybe who's first defensively. Um, so use that always to help me pick up players or trade players throughout the league. >> I always thought defensively I was pretty solid, but ninth out of 10 for clean sheets, that is where I am going wrong in this league. It's also got a lovely head-to-head feature, which is a live head-to-head. So on a match day it will give you updates live as to what's happening. On the left hand side of the screen you can see that this is taken from gameweek 24 where in this league there were five matches. The average score across those five matches and 10 teams was 42 and a half points. And down at the bottom of the screen you can see the individual matchup. So that week I actually played Whitefield's Warriors and edged that one and the league leader Liam Smith beat Gab Gabrielle Blide House in a very highscoring 5751. But it also has top scorers for every game week as well which is another nice little chart that you can follow. And on this week it was Hugo Eat who came out on top alongside Casemiro with Florian Vvers Domanki and Kenati making up the top five. Tell us about the transfer analysis tool. >> Yeah. No. So, in my league, we have one person that pretty much dominates our transfer window every every week. Um, with a ton of trades in, backup trades, waiverss, and so on. Um, so the transfer tool is just a way of tracking it. Unfortunately, the Premier League app doesn't actually provide you any of that stuff. It shows you during the week of, and then they disappear. Um, so this is a way where you can track, see how many trades are happening, who's has the most trades in your league, and what kind of trades they're doing, and just keeps a record of them. And then that way you can actually look at analysis afterwards. Was this trade good? Was it bad? Would this trade um have cost me the match? Or did it did it cost me or did it not? Uh did it make me lose my matchup that week? Um so it's it's really cool stat that it helps and you can constantly see who's trading for what. And if you want to maybe look at the next week's matchup, I'm playing against someone else, you can look at it and see if they're more likely to make a trade or not based off their previous trades as well. So, in this league after 24 weeks, 601 transfers. Is that above average, below average, or about about average? What do we think? >> It looks like it's uh it's a high number there. I won't I won't lie for sure. But, uh every season has people that are trading constantly, but there's there's been higher I've seen, and there's been much lower, of course. >> Good to know. Uh you did mention there that you can track good transfers and bad transfers, and this is another bragging rights kind of feature. It lists the best trade of the season in your individual leagues and the worst trade of the season in your individual leagues. So in this league, Burke has the bragging rights because he traded out Meankovic in game week six and brought in Alderete of Sunderland, which gave him a plus 16 point swing. And Liam may be top of the league, but he had a stinker in gameweek 12, transferring out Marillo for Van Hec and costing himself 15 points in the process. So, another lovely little feature there that really does get you the sort of the adrenaline pumping when it comes to your rival managers. We talked a little bit earlier about unlucky analysis. We've got on screen what it is on the app then how it explains it, but do you want to just talk us through this again? >> Yeah, so pretty much this is the way that I calculate if you're lucky or unlucky. Um, so an unlucky loss, you scored above the median and you still lost or uh if you're lucky, you scored below the median and you won. And then we calculate something called a luck score. So we take if you the amount of luck like lucky wins you've had and we take the unlucky losses and we calculate your score overall. So that way we can calculate if you wanted to look at who's unlucky but at the same time maybe you've been lucky a bunch of times as well >> in your league. Are you a lucky manager? >> I am I think I'm on the average or I'm one above lucky. There are much luckier people in my league and there are much unlucky much more people that are unlucky in my league. So, I'm in the middle. So, >> okay. Well, let's take a look what it's like in this league. The most unlucky manager is Tark Life, managed by James Doyle, who has had three unlucky losses, which means he's down minus three on luck because he has had no lucky wins. On the right hand side of the screen, you can see how this plays out. I'm pretty unlucky as well, by the way. Two unlucky losses, no no lucky wins. Murder on the Dano has had a bit of luck and a bit of bad luck. Three unlucky losses, two lucky wins. And Isaac Kaer, two unlucky losses, and one lucky win. But look who's at the bottom of that table. Mike Whitefield in second place in the league. Two unlucky losses, five lucky wins. when you look at something like that and and also I should say by the way Liam is in fifth for luck rankings. Two unlucky losses, two lucky wins. So he's breaking even. When you look at Mike Whitefield there, is that telling us that he's maybe in a position that he perhaps shouldn't be in. >> Could be, could be not. Time will only tell. >> Time will only tell. Very, very diplomatic of you there, David. I appreciate that. Let's talk about the whatif analysis then. So tell us what this is that we're looking at on screen. >> Yeah, so this is a hypothetical um scenario where if I I will take my team or my uh and compare it with the rest of the league and if I was to have someone else's matchups. So it shows me in this purple little window your current position uh your actual record. So your wins, draws, and losses and your luck factor. And then afterwards um there will be a drop-own menu where you can go and you'll see if I had someone else's schedule where you would actually rank. Um, so that way you can actually see what if I had someone else's, I I I would have been first maybe or maybe you would have been last or maybe first would have been last if they had my schedule. We never know. So this is an actual way of calculating every single scenario that's out there and um and just showing you in your league where you would have ranked. And I feel like we're picking a bit on Mike here, but we the only reason we've used Whitefield's Warriors here is because his league position changes so much based on each manager's schedule. So, we're going to have a look at that now. So, if he had the schedule of Liam Smith, who's top of the league, Mike, who is currently second, would be down one place in third. I'm in third place at the moment. If he had my schedule, he'd be down in fourth. But if you look on the right hand side of this screen if he had Burke's fixture schedule, he wouldn't be second in the league. He would be bottom of the league. I mean, that is an absolutely unbelievable statistic and it's something that you just cannot get anywhere else. No, you can't. And it's it's something that uh shocks everyone when they see it. And and there's even a tool beside it. There's another tab where it'll allow you to see the breakdown of week by week. Some people don't believe it, but that way you can track it week by week and see it. But yeah, maybe he's just lucky that he got his schedule then and not Burks. It looks like >> it does [laughter] look that way, doesn't it? It does. If he wins the league, my god. Okay, let's take a look at bench points lost. This is another tool that again I have not seen anywhere else. So, why don't you tell us about this? >> Yeah, I know. So, um, typically we have people in our league that are always leaving players on the bench, always picking the wrong players to start and losing so many points on the bench and losing game week. So, this is just a way to track like every week how many points were lost on your bench and how many and week by week who the who the player was and how many points that was. And then at the end, it's nice to see like who had the most and who had the least. And it could have been from injuries, could have been from just poor man team management. I guess you'll have to do a further analysis for that. >> I was going to say it's either poor management or bad luck or a bit of both. In this league, 1,339 points have been left on the bench in the first 24 weeks of this season. That's an average of 134 points per manager. But the manager who has wasted the most points by benching players he shouldn't have is James Doyle, who has cost himself 206 points. And by contrast, Liam Smith, who is top of the league, has cost himself just 135. When you look at this, and you've obviously got access to all sorts of leagues, and you and you you use your leagues presumably in your app, is 206 points a lot of points to leave on the bench, or is that is that an acceptable amount? >> I won't lie, it is a lot more than what we have in our league and it is uh typically more than the average. Um, but there are leagues that actually have more than that. Um, but everyone plays differently. Everyone is unlucky at times. Benching players or sometimes the smaller leagues, they have better players and their bench is typically better players that are possibly going to high have a higher ceiling. Uh, but in this scenario, it it does seem high for a 10erson league. >> Okay, that's interesting to know, James. Do better, my friend. Do better. Okay, let's talk win streaks. This is another nice little feature you've got. What's this all about? >> Yeah, this is a way of just seeing who who's on fire, who's basically um like like winning their games, who's losing their games in a row. And then the longest unbeaten is even with ties, like with draws, any kind of draws that are there. So, looks like Liam is on a winning streak, and we're going to see who's going to be the one to break it. Um, and then Richard, he's on a losing streak, but I guess he Richard's got to do something different uh to break this losing streak of his. >> Yeah, I I think if you get three plus wins, you're classed as on fire. If you get three plus losses, you're classed as ice cold. And then the season records, again, nice bragging right opportunity for you. So, the longest win streak in this league, Liam Smith with six wins. The longest unbeaten, eight games again, Liam Smith. and the longest losing streak, Richard Ellinger with nine losses. Although I should say Richard is now no longer bottom of this league. So well done to Richard for plugging away and finally getting himself off the bottom of that league. Tell us about this as well. This is the end of season summary. So this is another tool that you offer at the end of each campaign. >> Yeah, so this is something that I came up with last season. Um I was when I would pull the data and all that, the data is typically deleted at the end of the season. Um, so I wanted a way of keeping remembering the previous seasons on how did everyone do? Um, what was your squad? Um, how did everyone rank compared to everyone? So this is just something that I created and it it basically every manager is listed at the very top in a certain color with their points and you basically follow your color. So you'll see when you go down you'll have your MVP player. So the player that you had on your squad throughout your season that got you the most points. You'll see a breakdown in a little bit of circle graphs. you'll see uh a breakdown of where majority of the points came that season. Was it from forwards, midfielders, defenders? Um and that can help you with planning your next season can help you planning this season. And then at the end of this whole PDF is my favorite feature is where you see your starting 11, your top players that with all the trades that you've been doing that got you the most points throughout the entire season that year. Um and just a little visual so you can see everyone and it's a nice way of just keeping record of that season. This is how we all did. >> It's lovely stuff. So, when you started this app, before you launched it and you kept it to yourself and you were testing and testing and testing, was there not a part of you that thought, I'm going to absolutely coast my leagues if I keep this to myself? >> I I I wish that was the case, but uh in the end, there's so much stats, there's so much uh stuff that happens, but you never know what's going to happen. You're going to find a player that was dominating in the previous season not dominating in this coming season and vice versa. The players that come out of nowhere that just start an amazing form scoring goals, defensive contributions, a new rule that came out of there. So stuff's always changing. There's so many factors and this is just one tool that can help you, I guess, optimize and probably make better decisions. But in the end of the day, unfortunately, there's no tool that can just win you the league for you. And there are so many amazing features, the sort of features that I have never seen anywhere else, which makes it so good. Have you got any in the back of your mind where you're like, I haven't actually introduced this feature yet, but this is next on my list of the things I want to bring to this app. >> Yeah. No, so we have a handful of features that I have uh me and a group my friends and all the feedback I've gotten from just users throughout the uh using it because I'm active user on this as well. I we have our iOS app that just came out and I love the widgets. Um, so I have a widget that you can see all the scores, everyone head-to-head. Uh, but every week I there's more features that I'm planning on working on in development, but um I guess we'll have to wait to see them all come out. >> And you mentioned there that it is available on the App Store for iPhone users. When is it going to be available for Android users? >> So, we're hoping or I'm hoping in 3 weeks. uh roughly is a rough timeline, but um it's all going to depend on I guess how far I get in development in that side and the approval process with the Google Play Store. Um so all a bunch of factors to take into account, but I'm hoping as soon as possible, >> but in the meantime, it is available online as well at fantasyfooty.xyz. Would you ever consider approaching Fantasy Premier League and saying, do you want to get into into a partnership with this? Is that is that your end goal or is this really just something that you you're sort of seeing where you can take it? >> Yeah. No. Um so I this was always just a passion of mine just trying to calculate if I was unlucky and lucky and turned into something really big with a lot of uh interest from others. Uh but no, I would love it if the Premier League could integrate all these features, all these metrics and all this directly into their app. I have no problem helping them with that. or if they want to kind of have a way to connect this app to that one at their own, that would be great as well. Um, but I think it's something I'll continue to work on just in my meantime and spend to improve as much as I can just for any FPL draft users. Just feel like it's neglected a little bit on the FPL app. It absolutely is. So, David, one other question I have for you is obviously you've got the standard app elements, but you've also got the premium elements. So, if you want access to the premium elements, how much have you got to pay for that? >> Yeah, so the price is currently $5. Um, and then I think majority of people are using it in the UK right now and I think that's around 3.5 quid over there. Um, so um the goal is hopefully one day maybe we can get rid of the pricing uh and integrate directly with the Premier League. Maybe we'll take a different route, but I'm trying to get as much I'm trying to get the price down as much as possible um and just cover the cost of hosting an app and database and all this kind of backend stuff that the users typically don't know um is there. So um I'm hoping that it's not too much money for a person that's using it and um doing my best for everyone. >> It's fantastic. We're we're all extremely grateful. So, Fantasy Footy is the app. Tell us one more time how people can access it and how they go about getting it. >> Yeah, so you can access Fantasy Footy directly in the iOS app store by just searching Fantasy Footy and downloading it there, making your own account and they have a nice search on there where you can look up your league ID. U just writing your name or your league name or even your your the name that you made for your team. Um it's also available online on websites. So, fantasyfooty.xyz. Um, you can make your account there. There's a free version and a premium version there as well. And hopefully we're coming to um Android soon or Google Play Store uh for everyone else. Um, but that will be in the future. And we're on um Instagram X, Tik Tok, and we're hoping to expand further and further. Uh, but so far we're working our best. And if you have any questions there, my email is throughout so anyone can email if you they get stuck anywhere. >> Fantastic. Give us your socials then. What are you on Instagram and X? >> Fantasy footie. So fantasyfooty.xyz or just fantasyfooty. Um you'll be able to find us throughout um using that. >> Fantastic. David, it's been a pleasure talking to you. Thank you so much. I think it's a brilliant app. Everybody needs to go and check it out. It's got so many amazing features that you just don't find anywhere else. I'm very grateful for you spending some time chatting to me about it. That is it for this week's edition of the FPL draft and we'll be back very soon indeed with another look at another gameweek. But until next time, it is bye for now. [music] [music]

u5j0ixnwoiU.transcript: Cole Palmer is unsurprisingly the most transferred in player this round. Over 95,000 managers have already transferred in the Chelsea player. Another penalty goal in gameweek 26. His Chelsea teammate J Pedro is the second most transferred in. He always appears on these lists at the moment because of the fantastic form that he's in. In this game in gameweek 26, he had seven shots in the box, which was the highest in any Premier League match he's ever played. And his 48 points from his last five matches is the best run of any player. Anton Semeno makes up the top three for the most transferred in. He's 14point hole in gameweek 26 shows just why he is so popular in FPL. With Cole Palmer and J Pedro the most transferred in players. Maybe it's not surprising to see Enzo Fernandez right at the top of the most transferred out list. He has been so disappointing in the last couple of weeks, especially as when K Palmer isn't on the pitch, he is on penalties and there's been three of those for Chelsea. But K Palmer has taken all of them. Now that the double game week is in play, Declan Rice is the second most transferred out player. Over 41,000 managers have sold the Arsenal midfielder despite the fact that he still has to play again in double game week 26. Declan Rice and Arsenal of course will blank in 31 and maybe that's why managers are getting off early. For the midfielder, Harry Wilson is the third most transferred out. A few weeks ago, he was the darling of FPL, the player that everybody wanted. However, he's risen in price dramatically and cost six million and has failed to return in the last three game weeks.

LXTXQfgxUtw.title: MO & SAM @FPLFamily  FPL EARLY THOUGHTS GW27 ⏳ | Fantasy Premier League Tips 2025/26
LXTXQfgxUtw.transcript: Hi everyone, welcome to Early Thoughts. Looking ahead of gameweek 27. And as you can see, the superstar Praz is not here. But don't worry, don't worry. I've got an unbelievable replacement. Sam, how you doing? >> I'm like the world's worst substitute for Pra. >> N you're an excellent substitute. >> Everyone coming here to see Pra, I'm really sorry. You're stuck with me for a little bit, but Paz will be back for 27 prop, but he'll be back for your final thoughts. So, he's he's only a temporary substitution. I'm like the interim. We're going to talk about some managers later, aren't we? So, we we'll consider me the interim manager while Pra is out of action. >> Praise hasn't been sacked like Thomas Frank. He hasn't been sacked. Don't worry, he'll be back. It's just uh you know these superstar content creators, Sam, soon as this FA Cup or international break, they're jet setting. >> I know. gone. Nah, they don't do content. >> He's like, "Sorry, guys. I'm out of here. I got to take my holiday while I can." He's like, "The Spurs players off on a 12-day break." >> That's what he's doing. >> Rest in recuperation. >> Exactly. Let's hope he does return like you said for final thoughts for gameweek 27. Um, great timing to have you, Sam. Great timing because a lot we're still we're recording Thursday night. The Arsenal game is currently on. We'll try and keep up with the updates on that. But also look what's happened at Tottenham. Just look at what's happened. What's going on, Sam? What is happening to your team? >> Oh, Mo. Do you know what?
